page.title: 01Commondale Village and Moors
page.content:
Commondale lies at the junction of three narrow valleys of Sleddale Beck, Raven Gill and Whiteley Beck, surrounded by rough open moorland, rising from 150m in the south to 325m in the north west.
Population 90, are commuter families from industrial Tesside 20 miles away and hill farmers scattered around the village. Lower land is enclosed by dry stone walls for arable grazing. Some commercial coniferous afforestation. Communications via unfenced roads, often blocked by winter snow, infrequent bus service one mile away and by railway. Peaceful unspoilt open habitat supports much wild life. Birds include grouse, pheasant, curlew, falcon, rook, plovers and gulls.
